properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected overnight and Wednesday. Snow squalls are expected to develop overnight and persist throughout the day Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are possible by Thursday morning with the heaviest snow falling during the day Wednesday. Northwest winds gusting to 50 km/h will also combine with the freshly fallen snow to produce blowing snow. Snow squalls are expected to gradually weaken Wednesday night. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T01:41:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T09:42:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4044364198.2019
Area: Mount Forest - Arthur - Northern Wellington County, Innisfil - New Tecumseth - Angus
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall still possible for southwestern Nova Scotia on Tuesday night and Wednesday, less likely elsewhere. Total snowfall: possibly reaching 10 cm in the southwest, with only 2 to 5 cm now expected from Halifax eastward Locations: Atlantic coastal regions of Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday evening until noon Wednesday for Yarmouth County to Halifax Metro and Halifax County West. Wednesday morning to Wednesday evening for Halifax County - East of Porters Lake to Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County. Remarks: An approaching low pressure system is now expected to track further south of Nova Scotia than previously forecast on Tuesday night and Wednesday. Snow is still forecast to begin over southwestern Nova Scotia Tuesday afternoon and then spread eastward, reaching Cape Breton on Wednesday morning. However, total snowfall is now only expected to approach 10 cm over the South Shore from Yarmouth to Lunenburg Counties. Due to the uncertainty which remains in the forecast track, the snowfall forecast may be revised as the system approaches. In any case, this snowfall event has the potential to create difficult driving conditions in some areas during the Wednesday morning commute. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T19:16:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T03:17:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3057155714.2019
Area: Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Guysborough County, Richmond County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected tonight and Wednesday. Snow squalls are expected to develop late this evening and persist throughout the day Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts near 25 cm are possible for southern sections of the Bruce Peninsula as well as areas south of the Bruce Peninsula. Northwest winds gusting to 60 km/h will also combine with the freshly fallen snow to produce blowing snow. While the highest accumulations are expected over southern sections of the Bruce Peninsula, sudden heavy snow and blowing snow are expected throughout the peninsula, particularly tonight. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T01:39:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T09:40:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1170442156.2019
Area: Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected tonight and Wednesday. Snow squalls are expected to develop late this evening and persist throughout the day Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts of 20 to 40 cm are possible by Thursday morning with the heaviest amounts falling during the day Wednesday. Northwest winds gusting to 60 km/h will also combine with the freshly fallen snow to produce widespread blowing snow. Snow squalls are expected to gradually weaken Thursday, however, additional snowfall accumulations are possible. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T01:40:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T09:41:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0442279345.2019

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 40. Extreme cold is forecast overnight with wind chill values reaching minus 40 or colder. Temperatures will warm up Tuesday afternoon when an area of snow will pass through. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T20:31:14-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: westerly 80 km/h, except 100 along parts of the coast. Locations: southern and eastern Newfoundland. Time span: this morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Lake effect snow from Lake Superior will weaken this morning. A brief period of heavy snow and reduced visibility is then expected early this afternoon as a cold front moves through the area. Additional snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are possible by this evening. Snow at times heavy will make travel hazardous due to reduced visibilities. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T02:05:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T10:06:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3125397382.2019

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Further snowfall amounts: generally 5 cm except locally 10 to 15 cm or more over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland. Time span: today. Remarks: While the setup for intense snow squalls is less favourable today than it was on Monday, snow and strong westerly winds continue to give blizzard conditions in many areas this morning. Conditions will slowly improve as the winds start to subside during the day today and more so tonight. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:

These wind chills will moderate by around midday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Further snowfall amounts: 2 to 5 cm. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: Deer Lake and vicinity and the Burgeo Highway. Time span: today. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. A building surface ridge of high pressure will give strong winds near the Richardson Mountains. Strong easterly winds of 70 km/h gusting to 90 will occur tonight and Tuesday giving blizzard conditions with near zero visibility. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Additional snowfall: locally up to 5 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h except up 100 km/h along the coast until Tuesday morning Locations: the Connaigre, Burin, and Avalon Peninsulas. Time span: tonight. Remarks: Strong westerly winds accompanying the snow squalls will produce poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve by Tuesday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-17T13:59:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T02:22:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0809374672.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A developing low pressure system will bring heavy snow to northern Alberta, beginning late this morning. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 centimetres are expected. Snow will taper off Tuesday overnight, as the low pressure system moves eastward into Saskatchewan. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A warm front and associated low pressure centre is just off Haida Gwaii and will move inland early Tuesday morning. Winds will peak tonight near 90 km/h ahead of the low pressure centre. As the low passes overnight, winds will ease and shift to westerlies of 50 km/h. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T19:09:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T08:19:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0582670260.2019
Area: Haida Gwaii, North Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. 10 cm of snow will fall over Fort Nelson and Muncho Lake - Stone Lake on Tuesday. Snow will begin Tuesday morning and intensify in the afternoon. The heavy snow will ease Tuesday afternoon in Muncho Lake and in the evening in Fort Nelson as the low moves into Alberta. The heaviest snow for the Fort Nelson region will be near and north of Fort Nelson, particularly towards the Northwest Territories border. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
